Artificial Pollination: One of the ways to pollinate plants in the absence of flowers is through artificial pollination. This can be done by using a brush or a small tool to transfer pollen from the male anthers of a flower to the female stigma. This process can be done manually or with the help of machines.

Wind Pollination: Wind can be used to the pollen from the male anthers of a flower to the female stigma. This process is by the wind, which is amation that moves pollen from the anthers to the stigma.
Water Pollination: Water can be used to transfer pollen from the male anthers to the female stigma. This process is known as water pollination, and it is commonly seen in aquatic plants.
Animal Pollination: Animals can be used to pollinate plants. This process is known as animal pollination, and it is commonly seen in plants that produce nectar or fruit.
Fungal Pollination: Fungi can be used to pollinate plants. This process is known as fungal pollination, and it is commonly seen in plants that produce mushrooms or other fungal fruiting bodies.
